div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head:
THE WAR.
JAPS ADVANCE ON KIRIN.

div.p: The Japanese have occupied Mienhauchin, which is on the Kirin road, 16. miles to the north-east of Kaiyuan.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
PEACE OR WAR?
RUSSIAN COUNCIL TO BE HELD.

div.p: It is believed that a Council will shortly be held at Tsarkoe Selo to finally decide upon the continuation of the war or otherwise, after receiving reports from Linievitch and the other commanders, and the Russian ambassadors abroad.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
RIGOROUS REPRESSION IN RUSSIA.
CONFLICT WITH SOCIALISTS.

div.p: A serious conflict has taken place here be*tween a crowd, composed of 1,000 Socialists, mostly Jews with red flags, and a mixed patrol

of military and police consisting of 20 men. - The police declare that the Socialists fired them with their revolvers, wherenpon the former poured several volleys into the crowd, killing four and wounding 40. Many arrests were made.
(Reuter.)
A policy of rigorous repression is being pursued in, Russia generally. (Reuter.)

Marked efforts are being made to conciliate Finland. The obnoxious military law, imposed in 1901, has been virtually abrogated, and the dismissal of the judges, who refused to enforce it, is rescinded.
(Reuter.)
Admiral Nibogatoff's squadron is anchored here.
(Reuter.)

div.head:
QUESTION OF MOROCCO.
TROUBLE BREWING.
THE SULTAN AND FRANCE.

div.p: The curtailing of the Kaiser's visit here is - now explained by a statement to the effect that the Emperor received on board a message from the Sultan virtually bailing him as a protector against France. The Kaiser, declining to endorse such sentiments, refused to land. The German Minister ultimately persuaded him to charge bis mind, otherwise German prestige would have suffered considerably

The Kaiser went direct to the German Legation, and did not enter the Moorish Palace, which had been specially prepared for - him. The upshot of it all is that the Moors and French are alike offended. (Reuter.)
The Emperor William has embarked again.
(Havas.)
M. Delcassé, on' receiving two deputies, stated that he would not make any change in French policy in Morocco. (Havas.)
The Sultan is said to have refused to accept the whole of the French reforms." (Havas.)

div.head: PRINCE OF WALES. UNDERGOES SLIGHT OPERATION.

div.p: A bulletin, signed by Sir F. Laking and Sir F. Treves, states that the Prince of Wales underwent a slight operation this morning, which compels him to keep to bis room for a few days. There are no grounds for uneasiness, and no further bulletins will be issued. (R.)
The Queen of England has arrived here.
(Havas.)

| Foot and Mouth DISEASE has broken out in Cairo.

div.head: ALL SAINTS'.--
div.p: Bishop Morley will hold a confirmation to-morrow at All Saints' Church, Cairo, at 10.30.a.m.

div.head: S.P.C.A.-
div.p: Mrs. Mosely has given a donation of £20 to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals at Cairo.

div.head: LUNATIC Asylum.--
div.p: Mr. P. Keith has been appointed molahiz.of the Lunatic Asylum at Abbassieh, as from January 1, 1905. Mrs. P. Keith has been appointed matron from the same date.

div.head: GREEK PLAYS AT ALEXANDRIA.—
div.p: The Theatre Royal company from Athens is to give eleven performances at Alexandria, and will open shortly at the Zizinia Theatre with the Plutus of Aristophanes.

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS Dogs
div.p: found in Old Cairo on the night of Wednesday, and morning of Thursday, and in the Bab Sharia district on the night of Thursday and morning of Friday, will be poisoned by the police.

The S.S. "Orient" arrived at Alexandria from Constantinople at 10 o'clock this morning. She is leaving on Saturday at 3 p.m. for Malta and Sicily. There were 173 tourists on board, including many well-known people.

div.head: Suez Canal.—
div.p: 12 vessels passed through the Canal on the 31st inst.,8 of which were British, 1 Austrian, 3 German. The day's receipts were frs. 357,179.39. For the minth of March the total receipts were frs. 10,624,196.75 from 410 ships.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS.—
div.p: M. Marrullier wishes us to correct an error which crept in in the announcement of his appointment yesterday. The post he is to fill is that of chief inspector of accounts, and not inspector-general of audits.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY.-
div.p: It will interest members to know that the handsome "objet d'art" offered by H. H. Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel for the best collection of 24 roses is being exhibited in Magnin's window, in Cherif Pasha-street.

div.head: St. Mark's CHURCH.--
div.p: As stated in the "Gazette" of the 28th últ., an augmented choir will render the sacred cantata "Holy City" (Gaul) in the church on the evening of Tuesday, 25th inst. It is proposed, we understand, to have a small orchestra and a piano.

div.head: "The PIRATES OF PENZANCE."—
div.p: The profits of the performance of "The Pirates of Penzance," given on the 18th February, in aid of military charities, amounted to £450. This sum has been divided as follows :- £225 to the Soldiers and Sailors' Families Association, £112 10s. to the General's Benevolent Fund, and £112 108. to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

div.head: "Ben Hur" IN ARABIC.—
div.p: A correspondent writes :--In your issue of Saturday you stated that Ayad A. Ghazuli had applied for permission to translate "Ben Hur" into Arabic. This work has already been translated into Arabic by the late D. C. Van Dyck and is printed, it I am not mistaken, at the Muktatal. Printing Office in Cairo (or the American Press at Beyrout) and is called in Arabic "Iben Hour."

div.head: GIRAFFES FOR THE "Zoo."—
div.p: Sir Reginald Wingate recently -sent home from Egypt a couple of young giraffes, which travelled under the care of the celebrated Carl Hagenbeck's best keepers. They are said to be the youngest giraffes ever imported, and were fed, during the voyage, on condensed milk given in enormous quantities. The giraffe is an exceedingly difficult animal to import. Giraffes were first sent to the London Zoo in 1836, and from them sprang the famous herd of giraffes for which the London Zoo was famous, until the herd died out in 1881.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE'S SPEECH. ADDRESS TO GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: .. THE PLAGUES OF EGYPT.
inces
The following is the translation of H.H. the Khedi ve's speech at the extraordinary meeting of the General Assembly of the Legislative Council:

Gentlemen, - I am happy to see you assembled here. In your capacity of representatives of the provinces you have exercised a satisfactory control of the measures taken by our Government since your last meeting for the prosperous progress of our country. Today I am highly pleased to address you on certain : questions which have interested you on several occasions, such as the extension of public instruction in Egypt and its propagation among all classes. The Government has answered your demands as far as its financial resources allowed, and thanks to its policy i and to the new financial system, it has been able to increase the budget for public instruction very considerably.. The Government will follow this course in the future as far as its finances allow: In the course of the year the Government has occupied itself with the question of public health and has allowed the sums necessary for an extension of the labours of the Sanitary Department, whose struggle against the cattle plague has brought about the diminution of the epidemic, and has freed the country from the danger to an extent beyond our expectations. Owing to the increase of transactions in land the Government has been obliged to adopt a reform which was ardently desired by the country, namely, the reduction of the stamp duties from 5 to 2 per cent. This reform has been met with universal gratitude and approval. To sum up, our Government is -anxious to secure in every way the prosperity of the country and to combat any evils that may afflict it. You are aware, Gentlemen, that last April Egypt was threatened by an invasion of locusts who attacked a large part of the country. The people were threatened, but the Government took immediate and successful measures to combat the plague. The cotton worm is the third plague which has attacked the country every year. If it continues its terrible devastations it may inflict fatal injury on the country's chief resource, the cotton crop. We must therefore join in the struggle against this plague and take the exceptional measures which the Government lays before you. You have been summoned to-day 'to examine its proposals with a view to the protection of the country's chief asset. May God enlighten and hearten you to work for the country's good." | To-day, at 9 a.m., the General Assembly met
to consider the projected decree relating to the measures to be taken against the cotton worm.

div.head: VICTORIA COLLEGE.
div.p: Referring to our remarks in yesterday's issue with reference to the new site chosen for Victoria College, we now learn that the committee has concluded an exceptionally favorable arrangement with Mr. Pericles Glymenopoulo, who not only has ceded to them a superficies of about 130,00Q pics of land at Ramleh fronting the Khedivial Palace, at the very reasonable price of P.T. 15 per pic, but has also made the very generous offer to lend the committee of the Victoria College & sum of £15,000 for the space of three years at 5% interest in order to enable them to commence the work of building the new college at once, which would not have been possible but for this offer, as we understand that the committee were not in a position to commence the building until such time as they had been | able to dispose of the land on which the present

college stands. There is now no necessity for any hurry in disposing of same. · Needless to say, the munificent offer of Mr. Glymenopoulo has been accepted by the com| mittee, and we certainly think that the thanks of the entire British community are due to this gentlemen for the great interest and disinterestedness he has shown in the matter.

div.head: ENGLISH EXPORTS TO EGYPT.
div.p: The remarks we made in our issue of Friday | last in our analysis of England's imports to Egypt, as disclosed by the returns of the Customs Administration for the past year, are re-echoed in the following paragraph from the "Review of Reviews" for March :

One of the most popular excuses for war is that it is necessary to cut throats to secure markets. Apart from the morality or immor. ality of this doctrine, our experience in Egypt seems to prove that although we spent millions in securing a predominant position in the Valley of the Nile, it is Germany, which never spent a penny or killed a man, that reaped the increase of trade. Twenty years ago | 57.7 per cent. of the imports into Egypt came from Great Britain, last year our proportion had fallen to 34 per cent. Twenty years ago Germany only exported 0.4 per cent. of the total imports into Egypt; last year she exported 4 per cent., a tenfold increase in twenty years. We lost 3.7 per cent of the import trade; Germany gained 3.6. Whatever else these figures prove, they do not exactly encourage the idea that fighting for markets is a profitable investment of capital

div.head: CONFUSION IN THE CANAL.
div.p: EFFECTS OF RECENT STORM.
IE
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).

Port Said, Sunday. On Friday afternoon, the centre of a cyclonic -storm passed over 'Toussoum, a canal station south of Ismailia, destroying all poles and wires in the district, so that both telegraphic and telephonic communication were cut off between here and any point south of Diversoir, and the banks of the canal were badly damaged in many places. At the same time the steamer "Birkhall" went on shore in the Small Bitter Lake, and owing to the Canal Company being unaware of the fact on account of all communication being stopped, the confusion in the canal I became great. All traffic was stopped at both ends by the "Birkhall," but ships were entering the canal both from Port Said and Suez, and when communication, viâ Alexandria, Cairo and Suez, was restored on Saturday morning at
half-past eleven it was found that there were | 22 ships south of the "Birkhall" and 19 north
of her. | At 2 p.m. yesterday, by the aid of two
powerful tugs and a steam launch, the "Birkhall" was refloated and traffic was resumed. The first ship reached Port Said at 9.50 this morning, after having been tied up for nearly 24 hours.
The Eastern Telegraph Suez Canal wires were temporarily repaired at 6 a.m. to-day and direct communication was restored.

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: Port Said, Sunday. The rumour is current that a further division of Admiral Nebogatuff's squadron will arrive | shortly. The chiet Russian secret agent arrived here last night.
MENZALEH CANAL & NAVIGATION,

We are informed that at the extraordinary general meeting of the Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Company, which took place in Cairo on the 30th ulto., it was decided to increase the capital of the company to L.E. 100,000 by successive issues at prices to be settled by the board of directors, and that the shares successively issued should first of all be offered to the holders of ordinary shares in proportion to the number of shares which they possess at the time of each issue.

div.head: SUDAN EXPLORATION.
div.p: A DEAL IN SHARES.
18vice
DOCTOR'S CLAIM AGAINST THE PALMERSTON |INDUSTRIAL AND FINANCE CORPORATION.

Mr. Justice Kekewich, in the Chancery Division on March 27, commenced the hearing of an action by Dr. Robert William Felkin against the Palmerston Industrial and Finance Corporation, Ltd., and Mr. Alfred Bridge, of 15, Cockspar-street, S.W., claiming rescission of an agreement to take 800 shares in the SudanExploration, Ltd., and a declaration that defendants were liable to indemnify plaintiff in respect to all expenses incurred by him in relation to the trasaction. In the alternative, plaintiff asked for damages for misrepresentation.—Mr. P. Ogden Lawrence, K.C., and Mr. J.H. Simmons appeared for the plaintiff ; Mr. Ashton Cross for the Palmerston Corporation ; and Mr. W.J.L. Ambrose for Mr. Bridge.

Mr. Lawrence said Dr. Felkin had spent some time in Egypt, and knew the Sudan well. When he returned to England, unfortanately for himself, he got mixed up with the defendant Bridge, who was a company promoter. He was first attracted to Bridge by an advertisement in a London paper for a gentleman to act as director of a public company, and willing | to subscribe £1,000. Bridge's exact relationship to the Palmerston Corporation counsel said he did not know; but he appeared to have drawn cheques in the name of the corporation and in | the name of the directors, Generally he appeared to be the company himself. Bridge first got Dr. Felkin interested in the Palmerston Corporation, and then, finding that the plaintiff know a great deal about Sudan cotton-planting and transport, he brought to his notice the Sudan Exploration Company. Bridge told plaintiff that if he would take 800 £1 shares | he should have them for £1,000, and that he would accept, on behalf of the Palmerston Corporation, a bill accepted by Dr. Felkin at three months. Bridge also said that he would be able to sell for plaintiff enough of the shares which he controlled, so as to give I plaintiff cash to pay for them -- that was to

say, that they were shares which would go up | on the market. Plaintiff was to retain the | balance of the shares left. Counsel said he thought he would be able to show that the corporation did not control the shares. Subse| quently Dr. Felkin attended at Bridge's, office, and accepted a bill drawn by Bridge. The bill was endorsed by Dr. Bryant: The bill found its way into the hands of a moneylender named Levene, having been discounted by Bridge, who received a cheque for £800. Plaintiff had not been able to ascertain what became | of the £800, and whether it went into the Palmerston Company's coffers, or into Bridge's hands. When the bill matured Bridge gave the money lenders two other bills, the premium for renewal being £125. Plaintiff went to Bridge's office and accepted the bills, which were again endorsed by Dr. Bryant. The | plaintiff was unable to find the money to meet

the bills, and there was no sale of the shares, which plaintiff believed were never in the possession or under the control of the Palmerston Corporation at all. The money lender brought an action against the drawer, the endorser and the acceptor of the bills, and judgment was obtained against both drawer and endorser.
Mr. Ambrose, interposing, said that judgment was against Bridge, but not by consent.

Proceeding, Mr. Lawrence said plaintiff settled the action by paying the money lender, as he was advised that whatever remedy he bad was in the present action. Counsel contended that plaintiff never had any consideration, and that he never saw the shares, and he did not believe that the defendant corporation ever controlled them. He believed that the £800 was got out of him by Bridge for his own person. al benefit. The corporation had put in & defence stating that it was always willing and ready to hand over the shares to the plaintiff, | and it denied that the policy and business of

the corporation were controlled by Bridge, nor | did it admit that such representations were made by Bridge as alleged by the plaintiffs, The defendant Bridge had pleaded that if he did make any statement or representations concerning the present or fature value of the shares in the Sudan Exploration Company, they were bona fide expressions of opinion.
The plaintiff, Dr. Felkin, was called, and was under examination when the Court 'adjourned.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: H. S. C.

At the last meeting of the committee of the Helouan Sporting Club, held in Cairo at the Palace of H.H. Prince Mohamed Aly, the hop. secretary laid before the committee the profitand loss account and balance sheet of the club for the season 1901-1905, which was considered most satisfactory from every point of view. No less than L.E. 760 were given away | as prizes during the season, and after paying | all that from the proceeds of racing a respectable balance of L.E. 150 to the credit of the club was realised, which together with the other sources make a total balance credit of over L.E. 500.

The programme for the ensuing season 19051906 was passed, and the sum of LE1,150 was granted to be given for prines. The value of the "Sahara Stakes" for maiden Arab ponies was raised from L.E. 180 to L.E. 200, and the "Helouan Derby" from L.E. 150 to L.E. 800. Full programme will very shortly be published. | Taking into consideration the fact that the existence of the H.8.C. does not date back more
than 16 months, it is, indeed, astonishing to "And the front progrong it hu already made,

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: THEATRE ZIZINIA
CO
Hier soir la compagnie Coquelin Cadet a donné pour ses adieux, le délicieux chefd'oeuvre de J. Richepin, "Cadet Roussel".

Le sujet est d'une fraicheur naïve, semé de notes gaies et drôles qui produisent le meilleur effet. | M. Coquelin Cadet a été comme d'ordinaire remarquable dans le rôle de Cadet Roussel, Mlla Moreno très gracieuse, dans celui de Delvaporine et Mlle Maufroy tout à fait bien dans le personnage tendre de Mariette. Les autres acteurs se sont également distingués, M. Mon. teux dans le rôle de Roussel ainé, Mme Bouchetal dans celui de La Maillard, etc:

La scène de Démocrite, jouée par Mile | Moreno et M. Jean Coquelin a obtenu un très vif succès de gaieté. La soirée a pris fin avec quelques monologues dits par M. Coquelin Cadet avec le brio qu'on lui connait et qui n'a pas été l'un des moindres charmes de sa tournée. De nombreuses corbeilles de fleurs ont été offertes aux principaux acteurs et actrices par leurs admirateurs. Ajoutons que jamais hommage ne fut plus mérité.

En nous quittant la Compagnie Coquelin Cadet laisse ici le meilleur souvenir. Elle a eu le seul tort de venir un peu tard, après que la public avait été fatigué par une longue sério de représentatious ; c'est là le seul motif d'un succès financier moins brillant qu'il ne l'edt été en toute autre occasion.

This Company is formed for the purpose of carrying on the business ot an Investment,Exploration^! Development Company, especially in Egypt and the 8oudan. ^ For some years private Syndicates have been exploring oonoesffons granted by the Egyptian and Soudan Governments with tery satisfactory results; districts previously unexplored have been opened up, aud laud hitherto of little value is now steadily improving in price, and is in great demand. The irrigation and reclamation schemes projected are likely to still farther increase the investment demand for laud In view of the above, it ia proposed that this Company shall pay epeoial attention to business connected with land development irrigation schemes, aud reclamation works. It is generally admitted that the many industries of Egypt, unler the careful supervision of the Government, are now malting stead, progress. It is - intended to act as financialagents in JJoodoi^ Fans and elsewhere for laud development, mining and other oompanies, and i. is anticipated that considerable profit will result from this source. In view of the increasing interest of Freooh Investors in Bgyptian Securities, it is proposed to open a Branch Offise ia Paris at a.: early date. As the success of Company of this nature is to a large extent dependent upon a thorough knowledge of looal conditions, it is extrem ely satisfactory to have secured the servioes, as Director and Agent-General in Egypt, of Mr. Hooker, late Geueral Manager of the Bgyptian Salt and Soda Company, formerly Direotor-Ueneral of the Egyptian Government Salt Department in Egypt ;his knowledge of the oonatry and local business conditions is probably unequalled. Mr. Hooker has consented to act for a period of three years, at a salary of £1,000 per anuum, with a farther remuneration equal to 5 per cent, of the net profits in eaoh year available for distribution among the shareholders ^whether distributed or not) in excess of an amount equal to £10 per cent, on the capital paid up on the Sharee of the Company for the time being issued. 100,000 shares forming part of the present issue have been underwritten at a commission of 3 per cent, with an over-riding commission of 1 per oent which will be paid by the Company. 'Hie Directors are interested as sub-underwriters, and each will receive the 4 per oent on the number of shares underwritten by him as follows: — Sir William F. Haynes Smith, 2,000 Shares; Major Villiers, 10,000 Shares; AIL Hooker, 5,000 Shares; F. Russell Roberta, 5,000 Shares; J.W. Matthews, 6,000 Shares j H.E. Crookshank Facha, 500 Shares. The preliminary expenses, including registration lees and stamp duty, legal expenses aud brokers' fees, the ooet of advertising aud issuing this Froepectus, down to and including the allotment other than the underwriting commission and brokerage, are estimated s £4,000, which will be paid by the Company. No promotion money has been or will be paid. The Company will pay a brokerage of 8d- per shares to Bankers on all shares applied for and allotted to the publio on forms bearing the Banker's and Broker's stamp. Applications for shares can only be made on the form accompanying the prospectus which ooc tains the particulars required by law. Frospeouisea and Application Forms can be obtained at the Uttioes at the Company, the Bankers, Broken and Solicitors, or from the Secretaries, and wiU be sent on reoeipt of a telegram addressed "Hooker Cairo." j This advertisement it not intended as an mntaqon to subscribe.

div.head: Equal Good For the lungs and the stomach
div.p: It has been truly said that " Nothing goes right while the stomach is ' wrong." 5 It is therefore important in treating lung troubles to keep the digestive organs in a healthy condition. That is just what Angler's Emulsion does; it promoted appetite, aids diges- tion and improves nutrition, while at the same time it soothes and heals the lungs and air passages. It is this combined effect upon the respiratory and digestive'organs that makes it superior to any other remedy for lung affections and wasting diseases.

div.head: Mesopotamia
div.p: The Mesopotamia treated in this report is the true delta of the rivers Euphrates and Tigris, and comprises the country traversed by the two rivers and thieir branches southwards of Hit on the Euphrates and Beled near the site of the ancient Opis on.the Tigris. From Hit to Gama, past the ancient Babylon, is the Euphrates. The Hindia Canal is the branch which leaves the Euphrates hear Mosaib and joins it again at Sawama, after flowing through -the Sea of Nejef. From Beled to Gama, past Bagdad and Am.ara, is the Tigris. The Hai Canal leaves the Tigris at Root and flows into, the Euphrates near Sheikh es Shayak. During the Khalifate this canal was the main channel of the Tigris. From Gurna,' the junction of the two rivers, to Fao on the Persian Gulf, the joint stream is called the Basra River. By the Arabs it is known as the Shaat el Arab, or the River of the Arabs. in. THE EUPHRATES. The Euphrates enters its delta at Hit, where there are excellent limestone quarries and bitumen springs. From Hit to the Persian Gulf, on a length of some 930 kilometres, the river rolls its yellow water through an open, plain, bounded on the west by the desert. Uu the east pr left bank, islands of the gravelly desert are met with south of Feluja and again near Mosaib. - , Ffom Hit to Feluja, on a length of about 130 kilometres, the river is broad,, varying m width from 250 to 450 metres, the current is about 3 kilometres an hour, aud the average . depth 3.50 mptres. The valley is narrow, liable to overflow in places in high floods, and irriga- tion is in great part carried on by "charads" where water is raised in bullock skms by means of a rope passed over' a pulley ami drawn up by mules or horses going down and up an incline. . From Feluja to Mosaib, a distance of some 90 kilometres, the average width of the river is 250 metres. The trough of the Euphrates is some 3 metres deep down to the level ot low supply, and a flood of 3.50 metres puts the country under half a metre of water, against which it is protected by dykes, which are not very effective, and are occasionally burst, causing serious inundations. The following table of mean heights of the Euphrates at Mosaib will give a good idea of the times of flood and low supply of the river. The figures are very approximati ve but they represent the best information obtained by me.

div.head: YOU MAY HAVE IT AND NOT KNOW
div.p: The kidneys are intended by nature to drain off the surplus water and the body's impurities You know how well and strong and robust yen feel when the kidneys are working right. You feel right in every way. But how do you feel when the kidneys become clogged and diseased 1. * Tired,, miserable, sleepless, nervous, rest- less, back lame, and acbjng and' weak—can't stoop, Can't staud without pain ; rheumatic, gouty, dizzy, ^eak; no appbtite, etc. These- symptoms and a thousand others come from the impurities in the blood, which sick kidneys have not taken out of the body. Doan'8 backache kidney pills tone and he»l the kidneys, and enable them to take all them disease poisons out of the system. The medi- cine's effect is quick and sure; it dees not act on the bowels, only on the kidneys and bladder. The pills do one thing, and do it well. Doan'8 backache kidney pills are for sa'e xby all chemists and druggists for P.T. 18 pe' box, or P.T. 71 for 6 boxes; or they may bt Jiad by post from the general agent for Egypt Mr. Max Fischer, Hotel du Nil-street, Mousky, Cairo.

div.head: Al Azhar University
div.p: The following articles translated from "Al Chark" give a fair, idea of one side of native opinion in reference to the A1 Azhar crisis : — "We refrained from reproducing the rumours published by our contemporaries in Cairo with regard to A1 Azhar until the storm had passed and the agitation was brought, to silence, and until our colleagues had saved themselves the trouble of disoussions and explanations. Now that tranquillity has beeu restored and the weather has resumed its former calmness, and the reser- vists of A1 Azhar have been allowed a free hand,- we may asktba reformers these questions: What will A1 Azhar become hereafter 1 and what will be the condition of its graduates once they have acquired the religious sciences taught in it ? Will it be more than a religious college wherein nothing but the Mohamedau law is taught, and the sheikhs, on being graduated, will they be acquainted with anythihg else besides religious questions ? Where will this great army get their daily bread once they have left A1 Azhar and become Ulema in reli- gion and' Imams of the believers I There is no monastery in Mohamedanism so that they might abandon this world,put on haircloth and live away in seclusion ; on the contrary, they will have to marry and increase in number, and this involves energy and skill to obtain the necessary means of sustenance'. Bat how can such persons take part in the dreadful battle of life unprepared for it and devoid of any social knowledge 1 Will the Hakkanieh (Ministry of Justice) find sufficient employment for all of them as jndges, bashkatibs, and muftis 1 This question deserves much medita- tion. The Grand Mufti of Egypt, Sheikh Mo hamed Abdou, as well as Sheikh Abdilkarim Silmajo, have both resigued their poits in the Council of Administration at Al Azhar owing to the objection of the majority of the sheikhs there to include any worldly (modern) science in the curriculum and insisting on confining themselves to religious studies exclusively." "In our issue of yesterday we expressed an opinion regarding A1 Azhar and said we won- dered whether thfese Ulema, with no experience of anything except religious matters, would be able to earn their living. A Moslem friend has just sent us the following communication in response to our questions : You have asked an important question with freedom aud courage at a time when other papers have passed over the terrible weakness in the re- gulations of the greatest Mohamedan uni- versity. Endless discussions are now going on in this connection, and a great number of our .earned sheikhs are complimenting each other on their escape from tne board of examinations, and are thanking God that they will no more become mathematicians, geographers, natural- ists, or chemists. This greatest ot universities contains ten thousand students ; each one ot them is strong enough to remove a mountain ; Alexander, Haunibal, and Bonaparte, who covered the world' with fire and blood, had not stouter bodies nor stronger arms ; neither were ihe students at Paris greater in number when in 1892 a prime minister apologised to them and excused himself. I had occasion to see a party of students at A1 Azhar whom I suppos- ed to be moving rocks and speaking mountains. I noticed one of them had a dispute with another on a certain matter of opinion, and a nig fight ensned : boxing, and biting were indulged in freely, and the earth trembleu with cries. On another occasion I heard some sheikhs speaking there ; so sweet were, their words, so plehsaut tneir conversation, so clear tlieir: minds, and so excellent their- charac- tera«-as to surpass all expectations. I heard one of them discuss a religious i .question with such competence and modesty aud con- vincing proofs as I have , never before seen or heard. This numerous army of human oeings should be the source of Arabic literature and the most reliable body on both worldly and religious science. It should be the equip- ments and weapons to Islamism, its peace,and its war. This force should be converted into virtnonsness ; this youthliilness into righteous- ness ; this intelligence and ability into fortresses and fortifications. A1 Azhar should be the centre of all hopes, and the object of the greatest care and attention. If.it become ill it should be doctored, and if it become crooked it should be put straight. But if all means have failed and there is no hope of recovery it is then right that it? should be thrown down stone by stone and demolished to the ground. "Have you ever seen a young sheikh in hi» first year at Al Azhar 1 It he preached in >■ village abd said to the inhabitants, ' God com- mands you not to sell your cotton,' do you i-hink any one of them would dare to sell one pound of cotton 1 And if he were to say that Ghina was a town at a short distance from Ghirgeh, and that it was rushing upon them to deprive them of their properties; would there be any one without a naboot, a rifle, or an axe, and would you hear anything but screams and cries 1 If plagiie, cholera, or fever prevailed in an epidemic form and this y.iung sheikh of Al Azhar came and said, ' 0 people, there is no contagion in Islamism, al is due to destiny,'would the Sanitary Adml nistration find any one to hearken to its idvice or follow its precautions ? Such is tb> fluence of these sheikhs upon the puhlii uinda that it is absolutely necessary that they should he intelligent and well-instructed. Al Azhar contains two distinct parties : the one composed of those who go. to study and learn, and the other of those who oonsider Al Azhai asylum ora place of retuge for those wli'i scape from military service or are tire' >f judicial supervision, or are sick of thi world and its disappointments. The former ac in accordance with the ' Holy Hadith ' : Seel knowledge though in China ; the latter atten- i t Al .Azhar not with the intention to study but merely on woount of itn being a ' Tikia ' wherein the greatest desire is to be left quiet in their beds, and be served with their daily food regularly. "This is the real cause of what is at present called disorder and trouble at Al Azhar, and which in reality is but a noble struggle for the better. Now that the reformers have relin- quished their posts iu the administration of that uuiversity, and that the reactionary party has gained a complete victory over the pro- gressive party, the only answer to yonr ques- tion is that the numerous body of students have completely detached themselves from public society so that they do not understand the public nor do the public understand them; they aot in a way which the public will not fol- low. When this great army finds itself without -work and without sustenance, it will spread itself among the people and infect their minds with every species of ignorance. It will ingra- tiate itself amoDg'the public by means of mi- racles and wonders, and will exert influence on their admirers with canning sorcery and magio to deprive them even of their clothingi The country will encounter enormous difficulties through this army. No cultivation will be com- pleted, no cotton will be sold, no precautions will be taken against epidemic diseases, no modem project of the oivilised world will be considered until the learned adviser has been consulted. It will not be unusual tosee acommonmanarguing firmly that the sun sets in the sea, and that there is a special moon for each month, and that no man should seek his bread but that the bread follows the man wherever he goes, and so on. I pray the gracious God that He may not reduce Al Azhar to such a state, and that that institution may be restored to its ancient position in the Moslem world, and that its members may become a strong army of pro- gress and usefulness.

II. — Qu'en outre, la Societe des Eaux du Cairo est chargee par le Conseil d'Admi- nistration de la Compagnie Frigorifique d'Egypte, d'offrir eft souscription aux por- teurs d'actions et de Parts de fondateur de la Societe des Eaux du Cairo, 7,136 ac- tions au porteur de la Compagnie Frig.m- fique d'Egypte, an pair, c'est-A-dire an prix de 4 L.E. chacune, enticement payable en . souscrivant, A raison de one action de la Compagnie Frigorifiqtie pour 10 actions (ordinaires on de jouissance) ou pour 10 parts de fondatenT de la Societe des Eanx du Caire. Tontes les actions de la Compagnie Frigorifique mentionnees ci-dessus, jouis- sent des memos droits et participant aux benefices du ler exercice. Les porteurs d'actions ordinaires ou' de jouissance et de parts de fondateur de la Sooiete Anonyme des Eaux du Cairo, sont en consequence invites : a) A presenter, A partir du 15 Avril 1905, au si6ge de la Societe des Eaux du Cairo, et aveo bordereaux numeriques par eux signes, leurs titres d'actions ordinaires on de jouissance et de parts de fondatenrs pour recevoir les actions de la Compagnie Frigorifiqne leur revenant comma indique snb I ci-dessus. b) A exercer lenr droit de sonsoription sur les 7136 notions de la Compagnie Frigori- fique mentionnees sub II ci-dessus, A par- tir du 15 Avril 1905 et jusqu'au 5 Mai 1905 inolusivement, au plus tard, au siege de la Sooiete des Eaux du Cairo, oh il sera tenu A leur disposition des formulas sur lesqueUes ils auront A indiquer les numeros de leurs titres des Eaux du Caire. Les souscriptions devront 6tre accompa- gnees: . ' 1. du versement A la Caisse de la Sooiete des Eaux, du montant des actions sous- crites. 2. de la presentation des titres de la Sooiete des Eaux pour 6tre estampilies. Aucune souscription ne sera re$ue aprfes la date sue indiquee du 5 Mai 1905.
